headline: Best Guacamole
description: The best guacamole recipe. For chips or a taco topping, guacamole enhanced with lemon and onion is a forever favorite. And it's easy to make.

video.description: This guacamole will become your go-to recipe--it's easy and delicious.
video.name: Best Guacamole

name: Best Guacamole

recipeInstructions.text: Cut avocados into halves. Remove seeds and scoop out the pulp into a small bowl. Use a fork to mash the avocado.
Stir in lemon juice, onion, olive oil, and salt. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for 1 hour before serving.

review.reviewBody: easy to make and always yummy.
I made this and I don’t get why the oil is used at all or why lemons instead of limes. And no cilantro?! There are better recipes guacamole.
This recipe is easy and yummy with the minimum ingredients. Next time I’ll add cilantro but it’s great without.

I used just under 1 tbsp of lemon juice as I didn't have a lemon. (not sure how much juice half a lemon renders)
I didn't use onion as I didn't have one, but I diced up a garlic clove.
I reduced salt as I found it very salty the first time I made it. I put 1/4 tsp of salt.
I used one tbsp of olive oil, based on reviews, and 2 sounded like a lot.
I made it every day for a week. So simple and so tasty.
I added tomatoes, small piece of garlic chopped up, a little jalapeño pepper, and dried cilantro since I didn’t have fresh everything else I kept the way it was and it is delicious
Amazing!
Not bad but I will add half the onion next time and will try using a white onion instead of yellow.
Light &tasty!
Very quick and easy to prepare. Perfect for last minute condiment. More simple guac than I am used to but still very tasty and worked well with my tacos and fajitas. Will most assuredly use again.

This was my first attempt at guacamole, and using avocado as an ingredient in my own cooking. I'm not what I was expecting but this was uninspiring. Not bad, just not interesting. As other reviewers remarked, perhaps garlic and cilantro would help. I ended up using it as a layer in a 7 layer dip instead of solo, and there it certainly contributed to the flavors.
This "Best Guacamole" is really good! I guess olive oil is the charm! Who knew? Thank you PHLOX for sharing your recipe.

I grate the onion so it is a pulp and add a tablespoon 
Sambal Oelek and and bit of pepper and juice of a full lemon. Also no oil. 
Excellent with a slight kick. Try it. You won't be dissapointed
For a little spice, use a medium or hot salsa instead of just onion. You can make your own salsa like I do, or use a good store bought one.
Great
Really tasty and easy to make - great recipe to make if you have a lot of ripe avocadoes.
I loved it it was so delicious!It was so creamy! Me and my family loved it.
This was so simple, yet
perfect, we loved it

If you like it super plain it's good. I prefer a bit more flavor. Omit the olive oil, add one minced garlic clove, chopped tomatoes, cilantro (sometimes I substitute the last three items with part of a can of Rotel Mexican style lime and cilantro diced tomatoes), finely chopped onion and for a little zip add a pinch of your choice of hot ground pepper (cayenne, chili powder or chipotle chili pepper). The flavors blend together nicely.
Great and super easy. I eliminated the olive oil because mine was a little soupy even before adding it. Maybe my lemon was too juicy.
The lemon juice makes it.
No changes and yes I would make it again.

I had very ripe avocados, lemons and an onion, but had no cilantro or tomatoes at the house. Was so happy to find this recipe! It was perfect, and will be my go-to recipe to use up soft avocados. Thanks!
My guests loved it!
loved it. but as good as my moms
I skipped the olive oil and added minced garlic

It tastes great right after making this yummy dip, but cold is even better. I did substitute the onion for dried minced onion since I am not a fan of raw onions. Definitely will be making this more often as I cant find a decent one in stores that taste as good.

I leave out the onions, but this is still a masterpiece every time. I prefer less rip avocado and use a fork to keep it chunky. When I don't have fresh limes, a tablespoon of bottled lemon juice does the trick, tho fresh limes or lemons are better. Absolutely perfect amounts of salt, oil, and citrus. Thank you for sharing!
This is a good base guacamole recipe. I usually add 1 tsp minced garlic and a pinch of cayenne pepper for added punch. Everyone in the family loves it.
Gotta love Guacamole! Tammy had half of it before I got supper done for her. Big hit

This is a really good base recipe. I decided to take it up a few notches with a finely diced medium sized red bell pepper, a couple of finely diced Roma tomatoes, a garlic clove chopped finely with some Kosher salt smashed into it.

THEN I started using Cool Ranch Doritos in place of regular corn tortilla chips. IDEA...I put a handful in a bag and crushed them up to a fine powder and used that as a salt substitue. And lemme tell ya....WOW! 

So, Cool Ranch Doritos as a salt substitute. 

Bam...perfect guac.
Could definitely use a kick. Try adding finely chopped jalapeno to taste. Chopped sweet tomato balanced it out as well.
Wonderful Taste!
I wanted a quick snack and I had an avocado. I randomly clicked on this and halved the recipe. I made it easily in 2 minutes and it was DELICIOUS!
I made this and we really loved it. My son in law said he used this recipe and we liked his dish. Now I can make it myself.

Basic Guacamole. Need Cilantro, finely chopped onions, diced Jalapeño or even better Fresno Chiles, burn off the outside, remove seeds and ribs. Lemon juice but don't over do it. 2 or 3 dashes of Worcestershire, finely chopped tomatoes. Salsa can be added if you want to spice it up.
There was a split amongst the raters: some preferred the smooth, creamy texture of this version while others rated it second best to the more chunky, tomato-ey version.
Making it again today - excellent recipe!!
No, it was just what I was looking for, perfect tasting. Thank you
Very good! I omitted the olive oil and tomato and added 1/4 t of Cumin. Hubby had never tasted guacamole before and he gave it "2 thumbs up." Thank you for the recipe.
My avocados must have been small because 2tbs and 1/2 lemon would have been WAY too much liquid. I used probably 1/4 lemon and 1tbs oil. My 7 yr old even loved it.

It was my first homemade Guacamole, and it was far better than most Guacamoles that I had in restaurants.
I changed the recipe just a bit to my taste. less onions and more lemon juice and a cilantro.
this is one recipe i will definitely make again.
Truly one of the best guacamole ever! So quick and so easy. I used only avocado and onion, used regular lemon instead of lime but it was delicious nevertheless

As written it is a good sandwich spread. I found it flat tasting for a dip for chips or crudites. Add chopped tomato , lime and some hot chilies and you can make it as spicy as you like or not. Yummy with any Mexican dishes as a topping. Enjoy!!!!
Never made guacamole in my life but I tried this recipe and loved it. It was a hit at the party!!
Simple and yummy! It was gone in no time. Used a half lime cause that's all I had. Also only used 1 tsp of olive oil. Added chopped onions, tomatoes and 1 clove of garlic. Super yummy!
As we say in Hawaii, "It was soo ono!" So easy to make and it tastes even better the next day!
This is a good recipe but I added 2 tbsp of cilantro, 2 cloves of minced garlic and substituted lime for the lemon to make it great. Thanks for sharing!

I tried this recipe - it turned out ok. I have to have freshly chopped cilantro in mine. I also like tomatoes , onions and garlic in there as well.

I end up making pico de gallo and mixing a few teaspoons in with the mashed avacado. (I make mine with minced garlic)
best (and simplest) guacamole I have made; even better than most restaurants!

This was super-easy to make and the bowls were cleaned out almost immediately at our party! The only suggestion I heard was many would have preferred more of a garlic taste, otherwise it would have been "perfect". Ask people if they are garlic aficionados and adjust accordingly- we will definitely be making this again!

Good starting point. Need cilantro,fresh garlic , Roma tomato deseeded . Love the olive oil just not as much. And I only use red onion. And never lemon always lime. Just personal choices. It's cooking you supposed to make it yours. Recipes are just a base
It was simple and excellent. I thought it would be too plain, but it was actually all that we needed to accompany our chicken fajitas.
Goes great with carrots!

nice simple Guacamole use a high-quality extra-virgin olive oil
oh and if you want to ruin it feel free to put cilantro in it

This was much better than I expected based on the ingredients. It's not a traditional guacamole, but it has a really nice, bright flavor from the lemons and olive oil. It definitely benefits from sitting for an hour. I tasted it right after I made it and the salt and olive oil were really pronounced. It all blends and mellows after the hour wait. Because this guacamole doesn't have any strong flavors like cumin or cilantro, it's really good as a sandwich spread in place of mayo.
I love this!!

Really liked the recipe! However, I followed the advice of Barb A. and I think this is what made it superb! Everyone in my family liked it and the entire bowl was gone within the hour... will definitely have to double the recipe next time! :) I also added a dash of cayenne pepper to give it a little kick.
This "Best Guacamole" was in fact the best guacamole I have ever made. It reminds me of the expression "less is more." Not too fancy but big on taste. Thank you PHLOX for sharing your recipe.
Good recipe; simple basic quac! I hate cilantro and was happy this ingredient was omitted! I did add some garlic powder, though.
Added tomatoes! This is soooooo good and healthy
Better as a condiment than a dip.
Wish I had read the reviews first. Found it a little bland and the lemon overpowered it. Next time I'll use lime and add garlic.
This really is perfect guacamole!

To make good Authentic Guacamole in this quantity, you'll need a lime, Not a lemon, quartered, a teaspoon of minced garlic and I like to add enough good salsa to make the Guac. a reddish- brown color. Leave Out the olive oil, the avacado itself has enough oil in it. Mix everything together and squeeze the lime over it and mix well. Add salt to taste and get ready to make a fool of yourself! This version is GOOD!
No flavor. Friend made it--no one ate it.

This would have been too bland for my family's taste. And I've never had to add oil to any of my guac recipes. Garlic, cilantro, finely chopped jalapenos and diced tomatoes are wonderful add-ins to any guac recipe. Also, I prefer limes to lemons. If you don't like cilantro or jalapenos, this would be a good recipe.

It sounds like a good base. I will be adding in tomato and garlic. However, I am here mainly to say, no cilantro does not have to be added to make a good guac or salsa or whatever. There is a chemical in cilantro that causes it to taste exactly like soap to some people, so to me it would be exactly like shaving in a bar of Ivory.
This is the basic recipe for starters but by far not all what guacamole can or should be. Cilantro, garlic, chopped green onion, tomato, and of course, chopped fresh hot pepper to taste.

First of all, I like guacamole a little chunky, it looks far more attractive and the avocado is taster when it's not pureed, as the photo shows.. It needed fresh garlic, zero olive oil, chopped pickled (or fresh) jalapenos to taste, fresh ground pepper, a teaspoon of salt, red onion chopped and a quarter cup of coarsely chopped fresh cilantro and LIME juice, not lemon, also lotsa people add a chopped tomato, which is lovely but you can't save the guac in the fridge for long with tomato in it......I guess if you've never had good guacamole, you'd think that recipe was ...meh...but seriously....Another tip to keep the guacamole for turning color (if you have any left over) is to pack it into a glass container with a tight fitting lid but before putting the lid on it, place a piece of saran wrap directly on top of of the guacamole and press it into it lightly so no air will come in contact with it. Then put the lid on.
Ole'

Pretty sure this recipe has changed. I have had it saved for years and used to think it was delicious. I'm am 99% positive that this same recipe used to include minced garlic, garlic powder, and onion powder. Recently I noticed that the recipe is different and I've been trying to remember the ratios of everything but I can never get it quite right. I'd love for it to be switched back because that recipe was much better than the one currently here.
Love this, have made it as written when I just want to taste the avocado. Have also made it with tomato, garlic, cilantro, and lime juice. Its the best, thanks for the recipe!

Good basic recipe. This recipe can be cut in half (1 Avocado) and it's enough for one family dinner. Add two cloves crushed garlic, the same amount of tomato as onion plus fresh cilantro leaves. Keep the seed in the container with any leftover guac and it will slow down the process of it turning brown.
So easy and SO DELICIOUS!! I did snip a little fresh cilantro into it, but it was perfect and authentic without the cilantro...I just happened to have some on hand.
Left out the oil, added cilantro and garlic. That work
Too blandWhere are the tomatoes, cilantro, jalapenos, etc. ? Great for people that like things that have very little flavor or spice, but definately not the best Guac!

I like this recipe for Guacamole. I like it because the taste of the avocado is not overpowered by other ingredients. I like to grate the onion in and do so to taste and also add the lemon juice to taste. I used a full lemon's worth of juice. I'm thinking it would be great with lime too.
I never make guacamole any other way now. Hint: Add some minced garlic too. Mmmm!
I'm going to try this recipe this weekend for a small dinner party. Thank you so much for posting a guacamole recipe WITHOUT cilantro which I'm highly allergic to!

I used this as a base recipe. I added 1 grated jalapeno pepper to add some heat, 1 seeded chopped roma tomato for texture, and a sprinkle of cumin and garlic powder for flavor. Let it sit an hour as suggested. Delicious.
This is simply the BEST guacamole recipe you will ever find.
Quick, nice color, great taste.
This recipe was good but it was lacking a kick factor. I prefer my BIL's recipe more.
Changed quite a bit using previous comments, but a good base.

An excellent tip to keep your Guacamole from turning brown without having to add lemon or lime juice. Do not discard the seed, when you have finished seasoning your Guacamole simply put the seed back in the bowl with the Guacamole, it keeps it from browning.
I added cilantro to this and used limes instead of lemons...and, how can guacamole be made without garlic! Added a few cloves to mine!
It was fabulous! Great way to get kids to eat avocados.....it was gone really fast.

This is a great recipe! I especially like that I don't have to add a lot of ingredients. 
The second time I made it I forgot the olive oil and we liked it better.
This recipe proved that you don't need a whole slew of ingredients to make a great tasting guac. All you need is this recipe and your tongue to taste!
I made this and it did not come out as I expected. I followed the recipe I guess I prefer a chunkier Guacamole. I will try it again with modifications.
I leave out the oil, sometimes use lime instead of lemon and usually add diced jalapenos for a little extra kick!
This guacamole is super easy to make and quite good! The only adjustment I made was to cut the recipe in half.
I don't eat guacamole, but my husband can not get enough of it! He RAVED about this guacamole for days! He said it is among the best he has EVER had! Definitely a keeper in my recipe collection!

Sorry to give this 1 star but this recipe just didn't suit my taste buds and I thought I would like it cause it reminds me of the method we use here in Trinidad to make "choka" from lots of different veggies (and some veggies which are classed as fruits.) I even added in some chopped up habanero pepper to make it more like choka. But I think I will stick to eating my avocados plain cause all I felt I tasted were lemon and onions and none of that wonderful sweet avocado taste :(.

I thought this tasted pretty good. I normally make guacamole to taste and without a recipe, but decided to try one to see if there was a difference. I garnished with tomatoes and onions and ate it with baked tortilla chips. I realized after I started eating it that I forgot the olive oil! I had never heard of putting olive oil in it anyway. I thought it was a tad lemony, but maybe it will stay a bright green color this time in the fridge. I did use probably a little less lemon, than what was suggested, and I also chopped the onion quite small. The main thing that surprised me about the recipe was the 16 servings, I was lucky to get 3 small servings. I will make this again, when I don't have all the ingredients of my typical guacamole, leaving out the olive oil as I did this time.
I don't eat it, but my husband really enjoyed this guacamole. Thanks for the recipe!

This was my first time making guac and this recipe was easy and delicious!! It went up against another guac, with salsa and beans in it, and this guac blew it out of the water! Everyone loved mine and told me how much better it was. Sometimes simpler is better!
This really was the best guacamole. I didn't add the olive oil...there is no reason for it. I used lime instead of lemon juice but I don't think it matters. Delicious!
